name: 勞維俊
objective:
Course Aims:

The course provides students with skill-based instructions in learning how to read literary and cultural texts. Desired learning outcomes include reading skill development, vocabulary building, language analysis, and critical thinking. Reading materials encompass a variety of viewpoints on global topics centered on social issues, the environment, psychology, business, and technology. Extended activities are designed to encourage students to go beyond the assigned materials, and to put what they have acquired from the readings into listening, speaking and writing practices.

教導學生閱讀囊括全球議題的文章，並藉由文章的內容作技巧的訓練，字彙的建構，語言的解析，及思維的拕發。課中延展活動將閱讀內容與聽力、會話、寫作做進一步的連結，並引導學生將所學做有效的應用。
schedule:
Focus for Spring 2013: Art and Life (Friday)

Week 1: Introduction:
Calvino, ‘Why Read the Classics?’, Keats, ‘This Living Hand,’ Borges, ‘Borges and I’
Week 2: Holiday (no class)
Week 3: Ibsen, The Master Builder 
Week 4: Ibsen continued
Week 5: Rope (dir. Hitchcock)
Week 6: Rope continued (D. A. Miller’s article on Rope)
Week 7: Holiday (no class) 
Week 8: On Nietzsche

Week 9: Mid-term exam 

Week 10: Freud, ‘Creative Writers and Day-Dreaming’
Week 11: D. H. Lawrence, ‘Morality and the Novel’ and ‘Why the Novel Matters’
Week 12: Terrorizers (dir. Edward Yang)
Week 13: Terrorizers continued
Week 14: Oscar Wilde, ‘The Critic as Artist’
Week 15: ‘The Critic as Artist’ continued
Week 16: Three Colours: Blue (dir. Kieslowski)
Week 17: Judith Butler, Precarious Life

Week 18: Final exam


Teaching Approach:

Students are required to read all the assigned texts, including literary, filmic and theoretical works. They should attend lectures, participate in discussions in tutorials, take a mid-term examination, give a group presentation, and write an essay.
